Adverbs and AdvP - Locative Adverbs Locative adverbs include the English words: here and there. These locative adverbs may be related to the .
In English, location is often also expressed by a prepositional phrase, such as: in the mountains, at San Jose, over there. Many languages allow just a nominal phrase, consisting of a proper noun or description of the place.
Think about how locatives are expressed in your language. For those which are adverbs, are there any degree words which can modify them? In English, this seems to be limited to only (a type of construction) and right, as in:
only here. only there. right here. right there.

RAdvPLocDem How are the locative adverbs in your language related to the demonstratives? The forms are completely distinct The forms are identical, but they are used in different positions in the sentence Some of the forms are identical, but other forms are distinct An affix is added to a demonstrative to form a locative adverb An affix is added to a locative adverb to form a demonstrative The two forms have the following other relationship in my language:
In the lexicon, you will need to have two entries for each word, one with the category Adv and feature locative and one with the category Dem. In the lexicon, key the features locative makeAdv on the affix that is added to a demonstrative to form a locative adverb, as this will take care of the category change needed. In the lexicon, key the features locative makeDem on the affix that is added to a locative adverb to form a demonstrative, as this will take care of the category change needed.
